moves.1. c4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. e3 Nc6 4. d4 Bb4: A blunder!  I am not too familiar with Queen-side openings and didn't take the effort to carefully analyze the position before making what seemed to me like a plausible move.
moves.7. Qa4+ c6 8. Qxb4: Resigning at this point was very tempting.  After all, I was down a bishop after only 7 moves, had nothing to compensate for it and that too against a player whose rating was around 100 points higher than mine.
moves.8... Qc7: I hung on though.  Simply because I figured it'd be interesting to put up a tough fight.
moves.9. Bd3 Na6 10. Qa3 Nc5: Moving the knight to a strong square.
moves.11. Bc2 a5: I knew his next move would be b4 to push my knight away.  Hence I played a5.
moves.14. Nce2 cxd5 15. cxd5 Nxd5 16. Rc1 Bd7: At this point, I was just trying my best to hold on.
moves.19. f3 O-O 20. Bc4 b6 21. a6 b5 22. Bb3: Here I saw that suddenly I had the game!  Not because I won the pawn on a6 but because my opponent's Queen was in a tight spot.
moves.22... Rxa6:
The queen has only two spots available - b2 and b4.  Either one leads to Nd3+ and the queen is gone.  

My opponent decided to resign at this point rather than play without his Queen.
